Award.AbstractNarration: The aim of this work is to develop a theoretical framework for understanding the linkage between genes (the genotype) and traits (the phenotype). The linkage between genotype and phenotype is complex, and there is at present no adequate theory that links genotype to phenotype. Development of such a theory is critical for understanding both organismal development and evolution. This is because development is the process by which phenotypes are made based on information contained in the genotype, and because evolution acts by selecting phenotypes, which then results in heritable changes in the genotype. This research will make use of a set of molecular, developmental and metabolic networks of different degrees of complexity, whose structure and kinetics are well-understood, to develop a theoretical framework to map molecular and cellular mechanism to phenotypic traits. Complete and explicit mapping of how genes are connected to traits is a challenging task because the molecular and cellular mechanisms that give rise to the phenotype are diverse, heterogeneous, and exceptionally complex. Previous theoretical work has used simplifications that do not account for the entire diversity of processes. Understanding how phenotypes emerge from systems that are inherently heterogeneous, non-linear and non-steady state therefore requires novel theoretical approaches that will be developed in this research. The project will contribute to an interdisciplinary education program that integrates physical chemistry, biophysics, cellular biology and computational biology for undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this work was to develop a framework for understanding the linkage between genes (the genotype) and traits (the phenotype). Complete and explicit mapping of how genes are connected to traits is a challenging task because the molecular and cellular mechanisms that give rise to phenotypes are diverse and exceptionally complex. Previous theoretical work has used simplifications that do not account for many of the complex processes. Understanding how phenotypes emerge from systems that are inherently heterogeneous, non-linear and non-steady state requires novel practical and theoretical approaches. 

 

We made the case that in order to analyze or reconstruct how genes affect a trait it is not only necessary, but absolutely essential, to understand the details of the causal pathway by which genes affect the properties of a trait. These pathways are complex, including the effects of other genes and of environmental factors, and they are invariably non-linear.  It is the pervasive non-linearity that makes analyzing the relationship between genes and traits challenging, and has made the standard statistical approaches to understanding how genes and traits are associated unsuccessful except in the simplest of cases. 

 

We used a number of systems in which to explore methods and theories, but have focused primarily on large metabolic networks and signaling pathways. The reason for choosing these is that the gene products are enzymes, transporters and signaling molecules, which have been extremely well-studied.  Both the topology of the networks and the kinetics of the component parts are well-understood. Thus we don’t have to black-box anything and thereby avoid the common problem others have of having to guess at parts of the network, guess at the kinetics, and make simple and unrealistic assumptions, which bring the usefulness and validity of the resulting models into question. We focused on networks that are of importance in human health and disease, because that is where the experimental data are most voluminous. In metabolic networks the link between genotype (e.g. polymorphisms for enzymes) and phenotype (metabolite concentrations and fluxes through particular reactions) is direct and involves no unknown intermediate steps.  Although these systems may appear to be simple compared to higher level complex phenotypes (like hands, eyes, faces), they nevertheless exhibit many of the properties of more complex systems, such as various types of feedback regulation, gene regulation, inter-compartment communication, and dependence on various environmental variables.

 

Perhaps the most important thing we found is that all systems we studied have extensive mechanism for homeostatic regulation. Homeostasis is stabilization against various  perturbations and should not be confused with the “steady-state”.  Steady-states are arrived at passively  whereas homeostasis is stability that is actively maintained, sometimes far away from the systems natural steady-state.  Homeostasis is an evolutionary adaptation to a varying environment that all systems are subject to, and occurs at all levels of organization from biochemistry to development to physiology.  We found that these homeostatic mechanisms also stabilize phenotypes against genetic variation. We showed that homeostatic mechanisms allow a great many “disease genes” to persist at high levels in human populations without apparent effect, and lead to disease only when homeostasis is somehow disrupted.

 

Our findings have profound implications for understanding the relationship between genotypes and phenotypes. Because homeostatic mechanisms buffer the phenotype against genetic variation they weaken, or can completely remove, the statistical correlation between genetic and phenotypic variation. This makes purely statistical approaches to understanding relationships ineffective. We showed that the effect a gene has on a trait is not a property of the gene itself, but a property of the system in which it is embedded.  What this means is that to understand the relationship between genes and traits it is necessary to understand the system that gives rise to the trait. Our findings suggest that there is no short-cut to a really deep understanding of both the structure and the kinetics of the system.
